fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.bodyText: Corrections made on theguardian.com on 21 April 2010 • Tories outstrip Labour in race to raise campaign cash was amended because a donor to the Conservative Party was named as Peter Harrison and erroneously described as the chief executive of Furniture Village. Corrections published in the Guardian on 21 April 2010 • A story said that, basing their case on the Human Rights Act, lap-dancing clubs were threatening to pursue appeals challenging local council licensing powers as far as the European court of justice. That sort of case does not fall to this Luxembourg-based EU court. The court involved, should domestic appeals under the act get that far, would be the Strasbourg-based European court of human rights. It operates under provisions of the 47-member Council of Europe (Lap-dancing clubs may take cases to EU court, 20 April, page 12). • In a Cryptic crossword (No 24,988, April 19, page 35) the solution to 21 across – Flying machine made from canes (5) – was given as Cesna. The make is actually spelled Cessna. • A story headlined Bankers under investigation (20 April, page 30) reported that Goldman Sachs was setting aside $5bn for what it termed staff compensation, but a subheading gave the sum as $5m. • Anglesey was relocated to "the shores of South Wales" from its normal spot off north-western Wales (The story of Obama's favourite chocolates, 20 April, page 2, G2). • When a report on the age of a possible ancient monument said experts had now carbon-dated the stones to about 3500BC, it should have explained that the carbon dating was done on the peat where the stones lay (Ancient stones found in Devon, 20 April, page 14). • A feature on parents who fought and lost in several elections (A vote for Mum and Dad, 17 April, page 1, Family) spoke of them out campaigning in the Gorbals during the 1982 Hillhead byelection. Partick was actually the Glasgow area meant.
